results.abstract: A 1964 meeting of Malcolm X, Cassius Clay, Sam Cooke and Jim Brown is the subject of Regina King’s riveting directorial debut.
results.title: ‘One Night in Miami’ Review: After the Big Fight, a War of Words

results.title: Good Luck Is a Curse in This Classic Film From Senegal
results.abstract: Ousmane Sembène’s “Mandabi,” about a devout Muslim man who comes into some money, is a post-colonial satire that’s still resonant today.

results.abstract: The streaming service’s movies feature Oscars winners and box office stars and are a reminder of its power in a Hollywood that has been irrevocably changed during the pandemic.

results.abstract: Films like “Promising Young Woman” should be especially urgent in the wake of #MeToo. Instead, they sell female characters short.
results.title: Rape-Revenge Tales: Cathartic? Maybe. Incomplete? Definitely.

results.abstract: Mr. Quiñones, also known as Shabba-Doo, rose to fame in the movie “Breakin’” and helped bring a distinctly urban kind of movement to the mainstream.
results.title: Adolfo Quiñones, an Early Star of Street Dance, Dies at 65

multimedia.caption: Adolfo “Shabba-Doo” Quiñones in a scene from the 1984 movie “Breakin’.” Produced on a modest budget, the film was a hit and made Mr. Quiñones one of the first celebrities of street dance.

des_facet: Total Blackout: The Tamborine Extended Cut (TV Program)
results.title: Chris Rock Re-edits a Special, and the Result Is Fascinating
results.abstract: With “Total Blackout: The Tamborine Extended Cut,” the comic effectively erases the stamp of the original director, Bo Burnham, and turns in a less intimate show.

results.title: Cuomo Outlines Plans to ‘Bring Arts and Culture Back to Life’
results.abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said that New York urgently needs to bring the arts back — not only to help jobless artists, but to make sure that New York City survives.
org_facet: New York State Council on the Arts

results.abstract: His output included “Coal Miner’s Daughter” and a James Bond film. But he was best known for his long-running documentary series about life in Britain.
results.title: Michael Apted, Versatile Director Known for ‘Up’ Series, Dies at 79

multimedia.caption: The director Michael Apted with, from left, Jackie Bassett, Lynn Johnson and Susan Davis, three of the subjects of his documentary “28 Up” (1984), the fourth in a series that began with “Seven Up!” in 1964 and followed the lives of a group of British people in roughly seven-year intervals.

The director Michael Apted with, from left, Jackie Bassett, Lynn Johnson and Susan Davis, three of the subjects of his documentary “28 Up” (1984), the fourth in a series that began with “Seven Up!” in 1964 and followed the lives of a group of British people in roughly seven-year intervals.

The director Michael Apted with, from left, Jackie Bassett, Lynn Johnson and Susan Davis, three of the subjects of his documentary “28 Up” (1984), the fourth in a series that began with “Seven Up!” in 1964 and followed the lives of a group of British people in roughly seven-year intervals.

results.title: ‘Mean Girls’ Won’t Return to Broadway
results.abstract: Adapted by Tina Fey from her 2004 film, the musical played 834 performances. A national tour is expected to resume when theaters reopen.

results.abstract: “The Rules of the Game,” directed by Jean Renoir, may not seem revolutionary, but thanks to its balance of form and content, it’s an enduring classic.
results.title: What Makes a French Comedy One of the Greatest Films of All Time?

results.abstract: The Netflix series, featuring Lebowitz and directed by Scorsese, offers acerbic commentary and a sense of yearning for a pre-pandemic metropolis.
results.title: Fran Lebowitz and Martin Scorsese Seek a Missing New York in ‘Pretend It’s a City’

results.abstract: Whether as tribute or corrective, these movies have proliferated in recent years in part because the studio’s trilogy has inspired strong reactions.
